levels.level: A fantastic start at the basics of publishing open data. It takes a lot to even get here.
Extra effort went in to support and encourage feedback from people who use this open data.
Regularly published open data with robust support that people can rely on to build ever more ambitious projects and ventures on top of.
This is above and beyond what’s expected - a fine example of information infrastructure for everyone else to aspire to.

question.label: What's this data called?
question.help: People see the name of your open data in a list of similar ones so make this as unambiguous and descriptive as you can in this tiny box so they quickly identify what's unique about it.

question.display: This data is described at
question.label: Where is it described?
question.help: Give a URL for people to read about the contents of your open data and find more detail. It can be a page within a bigger catalog like data.gov.uk.

if.requirement: You should have a web page that offers documentation about the open data you publish so that people can understand its context, content and utility.
You must have a web page that gives documentation and access to the open data you publish so that people can use it.

question.display: This data is curated by
question.label: Who curates this data?
question.help: Give the name of the organisation who looks after this data. It’s probably who you work for unless you’re doing this on behalf of someone else.

question.display: The data curator's website is
question.label: Where is the curator's website?
question.help: Give a URL to a website, this helps us to group data from the same organisation even if people give different names.

question.label: What kind of release is this?

option.label: a one-off release of a single dataset
option.help: This is a single file and you don’t plan to publish similar files in the future.

option.label: a one-off release of a set of related datasets
option.help: This is a collection of related files about the same data and you don’t plan to publish similar collections in the future.

option.label: ongoing release of a series of related datasets
option.help: This is a sequence of datasets with planned periodic updates in the future.

option.label: a service or API for accessing open data
option.help: This is a live web service that exposes your data to programmers through an interface they can query.

group.label: Rights
group.help: your right to share this data with people

question.label: Do you have the rights to publish this data as open data?

option.label: yes, you have the rights to publish this data as open data
no, you don't have the rights to publish this data as open data
you're not sure if you have the rights to publish this data as open data

question.help: If your organisation didn't originally create or gather this data then you might not have the right to publish it. If you’re not sure, check with the data owner because you will need their permission to publish it.

if.requirement: You must have the right to publish your data.

question.display: This data was
question.label: Was all this data originally created or gathered by you?

yesno.yes: originally created or generated by its curator

question.help: If any part of this data was sourced outside your organisation by other individuals or organisations then you need to give extra information about your right to publish it.

question.label: Was some of this data extracted or calculated from other data?
question.help: An extract or smaller part of someone else's data still means your rights to use it might be affected. There might also be legal issues if you analysed their data to produce new results from it.

if.requirement: You indicated that this data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't crowdsourced, so it must have been extracted or calculated from other data sources.

question.display: This data is created from
question.label: Are all sources of this data already published as open data?
question.help: You're allowed to republish someone else's data if it's already under an open data licence or if their rights have expired or been waived. If any part of your data is not like this then you'll need legal advice before you can publish it.

if.requirement: You should get legal advice to make sure you have the right to publish this data.

question.display: Some of this data is
question.label: Was some of this data crowdsourced?
question.help: If your data includes information contributed by people outside your organisation, you need their permission to publish their contributions as open data.

if.requirement: You indicated that the data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't extracted or calculated from other data, so it must have been crowdsourced.

question.label: Did contributors to your data use their judgement?
question.help: If people used their creativity or judgement to contribute data then they have copyright over their work. For example, writing a description or deciding whether or not to include some data in a dataset would require judgement. So contributors must transfer or waive their rights, or license the data to you before you can publish it.

question.display: The Contributor Licence Agreement is at
question.label: Where is the Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA)?
question.help: Give a link to an agreement that shows contributors allow you to reuse their data. A CLA will either transfer contributor's rights to you, waive their rights, or license the data to you so you can publish it.

question.label: Have all contributors agreed to the Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA)?
question.help: Check all contributors agree to a CLA before you reuse or republish their contributions. You should keep a record of who gave contributions and whether or not they agree to the CLA.
question.requirement: You must get contributors to agree to a Contributor Licence Agreement (CLA) that gives you the right to publish their work as open data.

question.display: The sources of this data are described at
question.label: Where do you describe sources of this data?
question.help: Give a URL that documents where your data was sourced from (its provenance) and the rights under which you publish the data. Do this even if the data wasn't originally created or gathered by you and even though you have the rights to publish it.
question.requirement: You should document where your data came from and the rights under which you publish it, so people are assured they can use parts which came from third parties.

question.display: The curator has published
question.label: Is documentation about the sources of this data also in machine-readable format?

yesno.yes: machine-readable data about the sources of this data

question.help: Information about data sources should be human-readable so people can understand it, as well as in a metadata format that computers can process. When everyone does this it helps other people find out how the same open data is being used and justify its ongoing publication.
question.requirement: You should include machine-readable data about the sources of your data.

group.label: Licensing
group.help: how you give people permission to use your data

question.display: Copyright and database rights are described at
question.label: Where is your rights statement?
question.help: Give a URL to a rights statement which shows who owns copyright and database rights to the data. This statement also says what you allow people to do with this data under licence and it helps them understand the terms under which you make it available.
question.requirement: You should have a web page that states your copyright and details of how people should give attribution to your data.

question.display: The rights statement includes data about
question.label: Does your rights statement include machine-readable versions of

option.label: licences
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about licences which affect your data so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about attribution of your data so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution URL
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your copyright statement about the URL of your data that must be linked to, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: other permissions or alternative licences
non-binding use guidelines

question.help: It's good practice to embed information about licences in machine-readable formats so people can automatically attribute your data back to you when they use it.

question.display: This data is available under
question.label: Under which licence can people reuse this data?

select.option: Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL)
Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

question.help: Remember that whoever originally gathers, creates, verifies or presents a database automatically gets rights over it. So people need a waiver or a licence which proves that they can use the data and explains how they can do that legally. We list the most common licenses here; if there are no database rights, they've expired, or you've waived them, choose 'Not applicable'.

question.display: This data is not licensed because
question.label: Why does a licence not apply to this data?

option.display: there are no database rights in it
option.label: there are no database rights in this data
option.help: Database rights apply if you spent substantial effort gathering, verifying or presenting it. There are no database rights if, for example, the data is created from scratch, presented in an obvious way, and not checked against anything.

option.label: database rights have expired
option.help: Database rights last ten years. If data was last changed over ten years ago then database rights have expired.

option.label: database rights have been waived
option.help: This means no one owns the rights and anyone can do whatever they want with this data.

question.display: Database rights have been waived with
question.label: Which waiver do you use to waive database rights?

select.option: Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence (PDDL)

question.help: You need a statement to show people you've done this so that they understand they can do whatever they like with this data. Standard waivers already exist like PDDL and CCZero but you can write your own with legal advice.

question.display: Database rights have been waived with
question.label: Where is the waiver for the database rights?
question.help: Give a URL to your own publicly available waiver so people can check that it does waive your database rights.

question.display: This data is available under
question.label: What is the name of your licence?
question.help: If you use a different licence, we need the name so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate.

question.display: This licence is at
question.label: Where is your licence?
question.help: Give a URL to the licence, so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate and check that it's publicly available.

question.label: Is the licence an open licence?
question.help: If you aren't sure what an open licence is then read the Open Knowledge Definition definition. Next, choose your licence from the Open Definition Advisory Board open licence list. If a licence isn't in their list, it's either not open or hasn't been assessed yet.
question.requirement: You must publish open data under an open licence so that people can use it.

question.display: The content is available under
question.label: Under which licence can others reuse content?
question.help: Remember that whoever spends intellectual effort creating content automatically gets rights over it but creative content does not include facts. So people need a waiver or a licence which proves that they can use the content and explains how they can do that legally. We list the most common licenses here; if there is no copyright in the content, it's expired, or you've waived them, choose 'Not applicable'.

question.display: The content in this data is not licensed because
question.label: Why doesn't a licence apply to this data?

option.label: there is no copyright in this data
option.help: Copyright only applies to data if you spent intellectual effort creating what's in it, for example, by writing text that's within the data, or deciding whether particular data is included. There's no copyright if the data only contains facts where no judgements were made about whether to include them or not.

option.label: copyright has expired
option.help: Copyright lasts for a fixed amount of time, based on either the number of years after the death of its creator or its publication. You should check when the content was created or published because if that was a long time ago, copyright might have expired.

option.label: copyright has been waived
option.help: This means no one owns copyright and anyone can do whatever they want with this data.

question.display: Copyright has been waived with
question.label: Which waiver do you use to waive copyright?
question.help: You need a statement to show people you've done this, so they understand that they can do whatever they like with this data. Standard waivers already exist like PDDL and CCZero but you can write your own with legal advice.

question.display: Copyright has been waived with
question.label: Where is the waiver for the copyright?
question.help: Give a URL to your own publicly available waiver so people can check that it does waive your copyright.

question.display: The content is available under
question.label: What's the name of the licence?
question.help: If you use a different licence, we need its name so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate.

question.display: The content licence is at
question.label: Where is the licence?
question.help: Give a URL to the licence, so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate and check that it's publicly available.

question.label: Is the licence an open licence?
question.help: If you aren't sure what an open licence is then read the Open Knowledge Definition definition. Next, choose your licence from the Open Definition Advisory Board open licence list. If a licence isn't in their list, it's either not open or hasn't been assessed yet.
question.requirement: You must publish open data under an open licence so that people can use it.

question.display: This data contains
question.label: Can individuals be identified from this data?

option.label: no, the data is not about people or their activities
option.help: Remember that individuals can still be identified even if data isn't directly about them. For example, road traffic flow data combined with an individual's commuting patterns could reveal information about that person.

option.label: no, the data has been aggregated so individuals can't be identified
option.help: Statistical analysis can aggregate data so that individuals are no longer be identifiable.

option.label: yes, there is a risk that individuals be identified, for example by third parties with access to extra information
option.help: Some data is legitimately about individuals like civil service pay or public expenses for example.

question.display: The anonymisation process has been
question.label: Has your anonymisation process been independently audited?
question.requirement: You should have your anonymisation process audited independently to ensure it reduces the risk of individuals being reidentified.

question.display: This data about individuals has been
question.label: Have you attempted to reduce or remove the possibility of individuals being identified?
question.help: Anonymisation reduces the risk of individuals being identified from the data you publish. The best technique to use depends on the kind of data you have and this is explored in the ICO Anonymisation Code of Practice.

question.display: By law, this data about individuals
question.label: Are you required by law to publish this data about individuals?
question.requirement: You should only publish personal data without anonymisation if you are required to do so by law.

question.display: The right to publish this data about individuals is documented at
question.label: Where do you document your right to publish data about individuals?
question.requirement: You should document your right to publish data about individuals for people who use your data and for those affected by disclosure.

question.display: The curator has
question.label: Have you carried out a Privacy Impact Assessment?

yesno.yes: carried out a Privacy Impact Assessment
yesno.no: not carried out a Privacy Impact Assessment

question.help: A Privacy Impact Assessment is how you measure risks to the privacy of individuals in your data as well as the use and disclosure of that information.
question.requirement: You should do a Privacy Impact Assessment if you publish data about individuals.

question.display: The Privacy Impact Assessment is published at
question.label: Where is your Privacy Impact Assessment published?
question.help: Give a URL to where people can check how you measure privacy risks to individuals. The ICO has recommendations about how to publish your Privacy Impact Assessment.
question.requirement: You should publish your Privacy Impact Assessment so people can understand how you have assessed the risks of disclosing data.

question.display: The Privacy Impact Assessment has been
question.label: Has your Privacy Impact Assessment been independently audited?
question.help: It's good practice to check your assessment was done correctly. Independent audits by specialists or third-parties tend to be more rigorous and impartial.
question.requirement: You should have your Privacy Impact Assessment audited independently to ensure it has been carried out correctly.

question.display: Individuals affected by this data have this privacy notice
question.label: Where is the privacy notice for individuals affected by your data?
question.help: When you collect data about individuals you must tell them how that data will be used. People who use your data need this to make sure they comply with the Data Protection Act.
question.requirement: You should tell people what purposes the individuals in your data consented to you using their data for. So that they use your data for the same purposes and comply with the Data Protection Act.

question.label: Is there someone in your organisation who is responsible for data protection?

question.display: The individual responsible for data protection
question.label: Have you involved them in the Privacy Impact Assessment process?
question.requirement: You should involve the person responsible for data protection in your organisation before you publish this data.

question.display: The anonymisation of the data has been
question.label: Has your anonymisation approach been independently audited?
question.help: It is good practice to make sure your process to remove personal identifiable data works properly. Independent audits by specialists or third-parties tend to be more rigorous and impartial.
question.requirement: You should have your anonymisation process audited independently by an expert to ensure it is appropriate for your data.

group.label: Findability
group.help: how you help people find your data

question.display: The data is reachable
question.label: Can people find more information about your data within three clicks of your home page?

yesno.yes: within three clicks of the home page

question.help: If documentation is reachable via links from your home page people can find it quickly without searching. You should make it more accessible on your website if they can't.
question.requirement: You should ensure that people can easily find your data from your organisation's home page.

question.label: Is your data listed within a collection?
question.help: Data is easier for people to find when it's in relevant data catalogs like academic, public or health for example, or when it turns up in relevant search results.
question.requirement: You should ensure that people can find your data when they search for it in locations that list data.

question.display: The data appears in this collection
question.label: Where is it listed?
question.help: Give a URL where this data is listed within a relevant collection. For example, data.gov.uk (if it's UK public sector data), hub.data.ac.uk (if it's UK academia data) or a URL for search engine results.

question.label: Is this data referenced from your own publications?
question.help: When you reference your data within your own publications you give it more context, and help people find and understand it better.
question.requirement: You should reference data from your own publications so that people are aware of its availability and context.

question.display: This data is referenced from
question.label: Where is your data referenced?
question.help: Give a URL to a document that cites or references this data.

group.label: Accuracy
group.help: how you keep your data up-to-date

question.display: The data behind the API
question.label: Does the data behind your API change?

option.label: no, the API gives access to unchanging data
option.help: Some APIs just make accessing an unchanging dataset easier, particularly when there's lots of it.

option.label: yes, the API gives access to changing data
option.help: Some APIs give instant access to more up-to-date and ever-changing data

question.display: The accuracy or relevance of this data will
question.label: Will your data go out of date?

option.label: yes, this data will go out of date
option.help: For example, a dataset of bus stop locations will go out of date over time as some are moved or new ones created.

option.display: go out of date but it is timestamped
option.label: yes, this data will go out of date over time but it’s time stamped
option.help: For example, population statistics usually include a fixed timestamp to indicate when the statistics were relevant.
option.requirement: You should put timestamps in your data when you release it so people know the period it relates to and when it will expire.

option.label: no, this data does not contain any time-sensitive information
option.help: For example, the results of an experiment will not go out of date because the data accurately reports observed outcomes.
option.requirement: You should publish updates to time-sensitive data so that it does not go stale.

question.display: This data changes
question.label: Does this data change at least daily?
question.help: Tell people if the underlying data changes on most days. When data changes frequently it also goes out of date quickly, so people need to know if you also update it frequently and quickly too.

question.display: This data is a series of
question.label: What type of dataset series is this?

option.label: regular copies of a complete database
option.help: Choose if you publish new and updated copies of your full database regularly. When you create database dumps, it's useful for people to have access to a feed of the changes so they can keep their copies up to date.

option.label: regular aggregates of changing data
option.help: Choose if you create new datasets regularly. You might do this if the underlying data can't be released as open data or if you only publish data that's new since the last publication.

question.display: A feed of changes to this data
question.label: Is a feed of changes available?
question.help: Tell people if you provide a stream of changes that affect this data, like new entries or amendments to existing entries. Feeds might be in RSS, Atom or custom formats.
question.requirement: You should provide a feed of changes to your data so people keep their copies up-to-date and accurate.

question.display: New releases of this data are made
question.label: How often do you create a new release?

option.label: less than once a month
at least every month
option.requirement: You should create a new dataset release every month so people keep their copies up-to-date and accurate.

option.label: at least every week
option.requirement: You should create a new dataset release every week so people keep their copies up-to-date and accurate.

option.label: at least every day
option.requirement: You should create a new dataset release every day so people keep their copies up-to-date and accurate.

question.help: This determines how out of date this data becomes before people can get an update.

question.display: The lag between creation and publication of this data is
question.label: How long is the delay between when you create a dataset and when you publish it it?

option.label: longer than the gap between releases
option.help: For example, if you create a new version of the dataset every day, choose this if it takes more than a day for it to be published.

option.label: about the same as the gap between releases
option.help: For example, if you create a new version of the dataset every day, choose this if it takes about a day for it to be published.
option.requirement: You should have a reasonable delay between when you create and publish a dataset that is less than the gap between releases so people keep their copies up-to-date and accurate.

option.label: less than half the gap between releases
option.help: For example, if you create a new version of the dataset every day, choose this if it takes less than twelve hours for it to be published.
option.requirement: You should have a short delay between when you create and publish a dataset that is less than half the gap between releases so people keep their copies up-to-date and accurate.

option.label: there is minimal or no delay
option.help: Choose this if you publish within a few seconds or a few minutes.
option.requirement: You should have minimal or no delay between when you create and publish a dataset so people keep their copies up-to-date and accurate.

question.display: The curator publishes
question.label: Do you also publish dumps of this dataset?
question.help: A dump is an extract of the whole dataset into a file that people can download. This lets people do analysis that's different to analysis with API access.
question.requirement: You should let people download your entire dataset so that they can do more complete and accurate analysis with all the data.

question.display: Database dumps are created
question.label: How frequently do you create a new database dump?

option.label: less frequently than once a month
at least every month
option.requirement: You should create a new database dump every month so that people have the latest data.

option.label: within a week of any change
option.requirement: You should create a new database dump within a week of any change so that people have less time to wait for the latest data.

option.label: within a day of any change
option.requirement: You should create a new database dump within a day of any change so that people find it easier to get the latest data.

question.help: Faster access to more frequent extracts of the whole dataset means people can get started quicker with the most up-to-date data.

question.display: Any errors in this data are
question.label: Will your data be corrected if it has errors?
question.help: It's good practice to fix errors in your data especially if you use it yourself. When you make corrections, people need to be told about them.
question.requirement: You should correct data when people report errors so everyone benefits from improvements in accuracy.

group.label: Quality
group.help: how people can report problems and improve your data

question.display: Data quality issues are documented at
question.label: Where do you document data quality issues?
question.help: Give a URL where people can report problems. People accept that errors are inevitable, from equipment malfunctions or mistakes that happen in system migrations. You should be open about quality so people can judge how much to rely on this data.
question.requirement: You should document any known issues with your data quality so that people can decide how much to trust your data.

question.display: Quality control processes are described at
question.label: Where is your quality control process described?
question.help: Give a URL for people to learn about ongoing checks on your data, either automatic or manual. This reassures them that you take quality seriously and encourages improvements that benefit everyone.
question.requirement: You should document your quality control process so that people can decide how much to trust your data.

group.label: Guarantees
group.help: how much people can depend on your data’s availability

question.display: The service that hosts this data is
question.label: What is the availability of your data?

option.label: you don't monitor its availability
there has been less than 4 days downtime in the past year (or equivalent)
option.requirement: You should ensure your data does not have more than 4 days downtime/year so that people can rely on access to your data.

option.label: there has been less than 2 days downtime in the past year (or equivalent)
option.requirement: You should ensure your data does not have more than 2 days downtime/year so that people can rely on access to your data.

option.label: there has been less than 9 hours downtime in the past year (or equivalent)
option.requirement: You should ensure your data does not have more than 9 hours downtime/year so that people can rely on access to your data.

question.help: Most server hosting providers have a service-level agreement (SLA) between you and them. This should guarantee uptime for the servers and determine the availability of your data.

question.display: The data is available
question.label: How long will this data be available for?

option.display: experimentally and might disappear at any time
option.label: it might disappear at any time

option.display: experimentally for another year or so
option.label: it's available experimentally but should be around for another year or so
option.requirement: You should guarantee that your data will be available in this form for at least a year so that people can decide how much to rely on your data.

option.display: for at least a couple of years
option.label: it's in your medium-term plans so should be around for a couple of years
option.requirement: You should guarantee that your data will be available in this form in the medium-term so that people can decide how much to trust your data.

option.label: it's part of your day-to-day operations so will stay published for a long time
option.requirement: You should guarantee that your data will be available in this form in the long-term so that people can decide how much to trust your data.

group.label: Locations
group.help: how people can access your data

question.display: This data is published at
question.label: Where is your dataset?
question.help: Give a URL to the dataset itself. Open data should be linked to directly on the web so people can easily find and reuse it.

if.requirement: You must provide either a URL to your data or a URL to documentation about it so that people can find it.
You should have a URL that is a direct link to the data itself so that people can access it easily.

question.label: How do you publish a series of the same dataset?

option.label: as a single URL that's regularly updated
option.help: Choose this if there's one URL for people to download the most recent version of the current dataset.
option.requirement: You should have a single persistent URL to download the current version of your data so that people can access it easily.

option.label: as consistent URLs for each release
option.help: Choose this if your dataset URLs follow a regular pattern that includes the date of publication, for example, a URL that starts '2013-04'. This helps people to understand how often you release data, and to write scripts that fetch new ones each time they're released.
option.requirement: You should use a consistent pattern for different release URLs so that people can download each one automatically.

option.label: as a list of releases
option.help: Choose this if you have a list of datasets on a web page or a feed (like Atom or RSS) with links to each individual release and its details. This helps people to understand how often you release data, and to write scripts that fetch new ones each time they're released.
option.requirement: You should have a document or feed with a list of available releases so people can create scripts to download them all.

if.requirement: You must provide access to releases of your data through a URL that gives the current version, a discoverable series of URLs or through a documentation page so that people can find it.

question.display: The current dataset is available at
question.label: Where is your current dataset?
question.help: Give a single URL to the most recent version of the dataset. The content at this URL should change each time a new version is released.

question.display: Releases follow this consistent URL pattern
question.label: What format do dataset release URLs follow?
question.help: This is the structure of URLs when you publish different releases. Use `{variable}` to indicate parts of the template URL that change, for example, `http://example.com/data/monthly/mydata-{YY}{MM}.csv`

question.display: Releases of this data are listed at
question.label: Where is your list of dataset releases?
question.help: Give a URL to a page or feed with a machine-readable list of datasets. Use the URL of the first page which should link to the rest of the pages.

question.display: The API service endpoint is
question.label: Where is the endpoint for your API?
question.help: Give a URL that's a starting point for people's scripts to access your API. This should be a service description document that helps the script to work out which services exist.

if.requirement: You must provide either an API endpoint URL or a URL to its documentation so that people can find it.
You should have a service description document or single entry point for your API so that people can access it.

question.label: How do you publish database dumps?

option.label: as a single URL that's regularly updated
option.help: Choose this if there's one URL for people to download the most recent version of the current database dump.
option.requirement: You should have a single persistent URL to download the current dump of your database so that people can find it.

option.label: as consistent URLs for each release
option.help: Choose this if your database dump URLs follow a regular pattern that includes the date of publication, for example, a URL that starts '2013-04'. This helps people to understand how often you release data, and to write scripts that fetch new ones each time they're released.
option.requirement: You should use a consistent pattern for database dump URLs so that people can can download each one automatically.

option.label: as a list of releases
option.help: Choose this if you have a list of database dumps on a web page or a feed (such as Atom or RSS) with links to each individual release and its details. This helps people to understand how often you release data, and to write scripts that fetch new ones each time they're released.
option.requirement: You should have a document or feed with a list of available database dumps so people can create scripts to download them all

question.display: The most recent database dump is always available at
question.label: Where is the current database dump?
question.help: Give a URL to the most recent dump of the database. The content at this URL should change each time a new database dump is created.

question.display: Database dumps follow the consistent URL pattern

group.label: Formats
group.help: how people can work with your data

question.display: This data is
question.label: Is this data machine-readable?
question.help: People prefer data formats which are easily processed by a computer, for speed and accuracy. For example, a scanned photocopy of a spreadsheet would not be machine-readable but a CSV file would be.
question.requirement: You should provide your data in a machine-readable format so that it's easy to process.

question.display: The format of this data is
question.label: Is this data in a standard open format?
question.help: Open standards are created through a fair, transparent and collaborative process. Anyone can implement them and there’s lots of support so it’s easier for you to share data with more people. For example, XML, CSV and JSON are open standards.
question.requirement: You should provide your data in an open standard format so that people can use widely available tools to process it more easily.

question.label: What kind of data do you publish?

option.label: human-readable documents
option.help: Choose this if your data is meant for human consumption. For example; policy documents, white papers, reports and meeting minutes. These usually have some structure to them but are mostly text.

option.label: statistical data like counts, averages and percentages
option.help: Choose this if your data is statistical or numeric data like counts, averages or percentages. Like census results, traffic flow information or crime statistics for example.

option.label: geographic information, such as points and boundaries
option.help: Choose this if your data can be plotted on a map as points, boundaries or lines.

option.label: other kinds of structured data
option.help: Choose this if your data is structured in other ways. Like event details, railway timetables, contact information or anything that can be interpreted as data, and analysed and presented in multiple ways.

question.display: Documents are published
question.label: Do your human-readable documents include formats that

option.label: describe semantic structure like HTML, Docbook or Markdown
option.help: These formats label structures like chapters, headings and tables that make it easy to automatically create summaries like tables of contents and glossaries. They also make it easy to apply different styles to the document so its appearance changes.
option.requirement: You should publish documents in a format that exposes semantic structure so that people can display them in different styles.

option.label: describe information on formatting like OOXML or PDF
option.help: These formats emphasise appearance like fonts, colours and positioning of different elements within the page. These are good for human consumption, but aren't as easy for people to process automatically and change style.
option.requirement: You should publish documents in a format designed specifically for them so that they're easy to process.

option.display: in a format unsuitable for documents
option.label: aren't meant for documents like Excel, JSON or CSV
option.help: These formats better suit tabular or structured data.

question.display: Statistical data is published
question.label: Does your statistical data include formats that

option.label: expose the structure of statistical hypercube data like SDMX or Data Cube
option.help: Individual observations in hypercubes relate to a particular measure and a set of dimensions. Each observation may also be related to annotations that give extra context. Formats like SDMX and Data Cube are designed to express this underlying structure.
option.requirement: You should publish statistical data in a format that exposes dimensions and measures so that it's easy to analyse.

option.label: treat statistical data as a table like CSV
option.help: These formats arrange statistical data within a table of rows and columns. This lacks extra context about the underlying hypercube but is easy to process.
option.requirement: You should publish tabular data in a format that exposes tables of data so that it's easy to analyse.

option.label: focus on the format of tabular data like Excel
option.help: Spreadsheets use formatting like italic or bold text, and indentation within fields to describe its appearance and underlying structure. This styling helps people to understand the meaning of your data but makes it less suitable for computers to process.
option.requirement: You should publish tabular data in a format designed for that purpose so that it's easy to process.

option.display: in a format unsuitable for statistical data
option.label: aren't meant for statistical or tabular data like Word or PDF
option.help: These formats don't suit statistical data because they obscure the underlying structure of the data.

question.display: Geographic data is published
question.label: Does your geographic data include formats that

option.label: are designed for geographic data like KML or GeoJSON
option.help: These formats describe points, lines and boundaries, and expose structures in the data which make it easier to process automatically.
option.requirement: You should publish geographic data in a format designed that purpose so that people can use widely available tools to process it.

option.label: keeps data structured like JSON, XML or CSV
option.help: Any format that stores normal structured data can express geographic data too, particularly if it only holds data about points.
option.requirement: You should publish geographic data as structured data so that it's easy to process.

option.display: in a format unsuitable for geographic data
option.label: aren't designed for geographic data like Word or PDF
option.help: These formats don't suit geographic data because they obscure the underlying structure of the data.

question.display: Structured data is published
question.label: Does your structured data include formats that

option.label: are designed for structured data like JSON, XML, Turtle or CSV
option.help: These formats organise data into a basic structure of things which have values for a known set of properties. These formats are easy for computers to process automatically.
option.requirement: You should publish structured data in a format designed that purpose so that it's easy to process.

option.display: in a format unsuitable for structured data
option.label: aren't designed for structured data like Word or PDF
option.help: These formats don't suit this kind of data because they obscure its underlying structure.

question.display: The data includes
question.label: Does your data use persistent identifiers?
question.help: Data is usually about real things like schools or roads or uses a coding scheme. If data from different sources use the same persistent and unique identifier to refer to the same things, people can combine sources easily to create more useful data. Identifiers might be GUIDs, DOIs or URLs.
question.requirement: You should use identifiers for things in your data so that they can be easily related with other data about those things.

question.display: The persistent identifiers
question.label: Can the identifiers in your data be used to find extra information?

option.label: no, the identifiers can't be used to find extra information
yes, there is a service that people can use to resolve the identifiers
option.help: Online services can be used to give people information about identifiers such as GUIDs or DOIs which can't be directly accessed in the way that URLs are.
option.requirement: You should provide a service to resolve the identifiers you use so that people can find extra information about them.

option.label: yes, the identifiers are URLs that resolve to give information
option.help: URLs are useful for both people and computers. People can put a URL into their browser and read more information, like companies and postcodes. Computers can also process this extra information using scripts to access the underlying data.
option.requirement: You should link to a web page of information about each of the things in your data so that people can easily find and share that information.

question.display: The identifier resolution service is at
question.label: Where is the service that is used to resolve the identifiers?
question.help: The resolution service should take an identifier as a query parameter and give back some information about the thing it identifies.
question.requirement: You should have a URL through which identifiers can be resolved so that more information about them can be found by a computer.

question.label: Is there third-party information about things in your data on the web?
question.help: Sometimes other people outside your control provide URLs to the things your data is about. For example, your data might have postcodes in it that link to the Ordnance Survey website.

question.label: Is that third-party information reliable?
question.help: If a third-party provides public URLs about things in your data, they probably take steps to ensure data quality and reliability. This is a measure of how much you trust their processes to do that. Look for their open data certificate or similar hallmarks to help make your decision.

question.display: Third-party URLs are
question.label: Does your data use those third-party URLs?
question.help: You should use third-party URLs that resolve to information about the things your data describes. This reduces duplication and helps people combine data from different sources to make it more useful.
question.requirement: You should use URLs to third-party information in your data so that it's easy to combine with other data that uses those URLs.

group.label: Trust
group.help: how much trust people can put in your data

question.display: The provenance of this data is
question.label: Do you provide machine-readable provenance for your data?
question.help: This about the origins of how your data was created and processed before it was published. It builds trust in the data you publish because people can trace back how it has been handled.
question.requirement: You should provide a machine-readable provenance trail about your data so that people can trace how it was processed.

question.display: This data can be verified using
question.label: Where do you describe how people can verify that data they receive comes from you?
question.help: If you deliver important data to people they should be able to check that what they receive is the same as what you published. For example, you can digitally sign the data you publish, so people can tell if it has been tampered with.
question.requirement: You should describe how people can check that the data they receive is the same as what you published so that they can trust it.

group.label: Documentation
group.help: how you help people understand the context and content of your data

question.display: The documentation includes machine-readable data for
question.label: Does your data documentation include machine-readable data for:

option.label: title
option.requirement: You should include a data title in your documentation so that people know how to refer to it.

option.label: description
option.requirement: You should include a data description in your documentation so that people know what it contains.

option.label: release date
option.requirement: You should include a data release date in your documentation so that people know how timely it is.

option.label: modification date
option.requirement: You should include a last modification date in your documentation so that people know they have the latest data.

option.label: frequency of releases
option.requirement: You should document how frequently you release new versions of your data so people know how often you update it.

option.label: identifier
option.requirement: You should include a canonical URL for the data in your documentation so that people know how to access it consistently.

option.label: landing page
option.requirement: You should include a canonical URL to the documentation itself so that people know how to access to it consistently.

option.label: language
option.requirement: You should include the data language in your documentation so that people who search for it will know whether they can understand it.

option.label: publisher
option.requirement: You should indicate the data publisher in your documentation so people can decide how much to trust your data.

option.label: spatial/geographical coverage
option.requirement: You should include the geographic area in your documentation so that people understand where your data applies to.

option.label: temporal coverage
option.requirement: You should include the time period in your documentation so that people understand when your data applies to.

option.label: theme(s)
option.requirement: You should include the subject in your documentation so that people know roughly what your data is about.

option.label: keyword(s) or tag(s)
option.requirement: You should include keywords or tags in your documentation to help people search within the data effectively.

option.label: distribution(s)

question.display: The documentation about each distribution includes machine-readable data for
question.label: Does your documentation include machine-readable metadata for each distribution on:

option.label: title
option.requirement: You should include titles within your documentation so people know how to refer to each data distribution.

option.label: description
option.requirement: You should include descriptions within your documentation so people know what each data distribution contains.

option.label: release date
option.requirement: You should include release dates within your documentation so people know how current each distribution is.

option.label: modification date
option.requirement: You should include last modification dates within your documentation so people know whether their copy of a data distribution is up-to-date.

option.label: licence
option.requirement: You should document applicable licences or waivers so people know what they can do with a data distribution.

option.display: a URL to access the data
option.label: URL to access the data
option.help: This metadata should be used when your data isn't available as a download, like an API for example.

option.display: a URL to download the dataset
option.label: URL to download the dataset
size in bytes
type of download media

question.display: The data API service is documented at
question.label: Where is the documentation for the API?
question.requirement: You should document how your API works so that people understand how to use it.

question.label: Do the data formats use vocabularies?
question.help: Formats like JSON, XML or Turtle need to come with a schema for people to understand it.

question.display: The vocabularies in this data are documented at
question.label: Where is documentation about your data vocabularies?
question.requirement: You should document any vocabulary you use within your data so that people know how to interpret it.

question.label: Are there any codes used in this data?
question.help: If your data uses codes to refer to things like geographical areas, spending categories or diseases for example, these need to be explained to people.

question.display: The codes in this data are documented at
question.label: Where are any codes in your data documented?
question.requirement: You should document the codes used within your data so that people know how to interpret them.

question.display: Find out how to suggest improvements to publication at
